rows: Police stopped Floyd after a market clerk called 911, accusing him of using a counterfeit $20 bill. For 8 minutes and 46 seconds, Officer Derek Chauvin pinned Floyd down with a knee on his neck, ignoring Floyd's repeated pleas of "I can't breathe," "Mama," and "Please don't kill me." After global protests, Minnesota Attorney General charged Chauvin with second-degree murder and the other arresting officers, J.Kueng, Thomas Lane and Tou Thao, with aiding murder.

Friends and family referred to Floyd as a gently giant. Texas raised, he moved to Minneapolis in search of a new start. He worked in security at a local restaurant, where his coworkers counted on him as someone who had their back and could be there to support them. Unfortunately, like millions of other Americans, Floyd was laid off due to the COVID19 pandemic. He was 46 years old and leaves behind three children.

Breonna Taylor was asleep in her home in Louisville, KY when policemen broke down her door. Executing a 'no-knock' search warrant for narcotics, Sergeant Jonathan Mattingly and detectives Brett Hankison and Myles Cosgrove did not identify themselves. Taylor's boyfriend, Kenneth Walker, believed them to be robbers and fired a gun at the intruders. The officers killed Taylor, firing eight times, and arrested Walker, charging him for attempted murder of an officer. No drugs were found in Taylor's apartment. Officers involved have been placed on reassignment and are currently under investigation, but no arrests have been made.

Taylor worked as an E.M.T. for the University of Louisville health system. Even amidst the pandemic, she served on the front lines to aid the sick in emergency situations. She graduated from the University of Kentucky and had big dreams of a life long career in healthcare. Friends and family remember her for her motto: "All you can do everyday is wake, pray, and slay." She was 26 years old.

Gregory (a former policeman) and Travis McMichael pursued Arbury while he was jogging through his South Georgia neighborhood. The father and son believed Arbery was behind recent break-ins in the area. Although the case went to court, it was cut short when prosecutors recused themselves. Proescutors cited a close relationship with Gregory and insufficient probable cause to arrest the McMichaels. The McMichaels have since been arrested and charged by the Georgia Bureau of Investigation, along with William “Roddie” Bryan Jr., who recorded the video of Arbery’s death. The U.S. Department of Justice is also conducting a hate crime investigation of the shooting.

Arbery loved being active and playing sports, of which football and basketball were his favorites. In high school, he was a star linebacker and dreamed of playing for the NFL. He had plans to become an electrician, and he attended South Georgia Technical College until family circumstances motivated him to end his studies. Many remember Arbery as a 'humble guy.' He loved spending time with his family and friends and lived with his mother in Satilla Shores, a small suburban neighborhood. He was 25 years old.

On July 17th, 2014, Eric Garner was approached by officer Daniel Pantaleo on suspicion of selling single cigarettes from packs without tax stamps. After Mr. Garner repeatedly protested that he was not selling cigarettes and asked the police to stop harassing him, the officers attempted to arrest him. Officer Pantaleo placed his hands on Mr. Garner, at which point, Mr. Garner pulled his arm away. The situation soon escalated. Officer Pantaleo placed his hand around Mr. Garner’s neck and wrestled him to the ground. With multiple officers pinning him down, Garner repeated the words "I can't breathe" 11 times while lying face down on the sidewalk. Soon after, Mr. Garner lost consciousness and the officers turned him to his side and waited for an ambulance. He lay on the sidewalk for seven minutes before the ambulance arrived and Mr. Garner was pronounced dead at the hospital approximately one hour later.

Eric Garner lived in New York. Mr. Garner worked as a horticulturist at the NYC Department of Parks and Recreation before leaving the department for health reasons. Mr. Garner was married to Esaw Garner. Friends described him as a "neighborhood peacemaker" and a generous, congenial person. He was the father of six children, a grandfather of three, and had a 3-month-old child at the time of his death. He was 43 years old.

There are still conflicting accounts regarding McDade’s death. He was a suspect in the fatal stabbing of Malik Jackson, which had occurred earlier in the day on May 27. Tallahassee Police Chief Lawrence Revell reported that McDade was in possession of a handgun, which he had pointed at officers before the shooting. However, eyewitness accounts and Facebook Live videos contradict these details, instead reporting that McDade was unarmed, and police began firing on him without warning. As of June 5, the identity of the officer who shot him is no longer protected under Marsy’s Law, a state law which protects the identities of crime victims.

McDade was a transgender man who used he/him pronouns. The night before his death, he posted a Facebook Live video in which he said he was the victim of a racist, transphobic attack and vowed retribution. He is the twelfth transgender or gender non-conforming person to be shot or killed in 2020. Friends and family remember McDade as "Tony the Tiger" and recall he had a big heart for others. He was 38 years old.

Police officer Amber Guyger was off duty when she intruded into Botham Jean's apartment. Entering Jean's living room, Guyger shot Jean and shortly afterward called 911. Responders took Jean to a hospital where he soon passed. Guyger claims she mistook Jean's apartment for her own and believed Jean to be an intruder; however, two independent witnesses contradict her statement, claiming they heard knocking and a woman asking to be let in. Jean's apartment was on the fourth floor, a floor above Guyger's.  Prosecutors also released several racist and violent social media posts, comments, and texts made by Guyger. On October 1, 2019, Guyger was found guilty of murder and received a 10 year sentence.

Botham Jean, know by many close to him as "Bo," was a man of faith. He approached his parents at the age of 8 asking to be baptized, and his faith continued to be a huge part of his life as he grew up. Jean involved himself in everything form preaching to church choir. He moved from his home of Saint Lucia to go to college in Arkansas at Harding University, but he returned home each year to give back to his community through volunteer work. He had a passion for singing, was a natural leader, and was well loved by many - 1,500 people attended his funeral. After his death, friends and family popularized the hashtag, #BeLikeBo. He was 26 years old.

On October 12, 2019, Jefferson's neighbor called the non-emergency number after they noticed that Jefferson's front door was open. When the police arrived outside her home, Jefferson came to the window to observe, which is when officer Aaron Dean shot her through the window and killed her. Police stated that they found a handgun near her body. According to her 8-year-old nephew, Jefferson pointed the gun towards the window before being fatally shot by officer Dean. On October 14, 2019, Dean resigned from the Fort Worth Police Department and was arrested on a murder charge. On December 20, 2019, Dean was indicted for murder.

Atatiana Koquice Jefferson attended Xavier University of Louisiana, where she graduated in 2014 with a degree in biology. She dreamed of one day becoming a doctor. In the last chapters of her life, Jefferson was selling medical equipment and saving to apply for medical school. But after her mother got sick, Jefferson agreed to move away from Dallas, where she had been living with a roommate, to Fort Worth, to live with her mother, sister Amber Carr and Amber’s sons, who are 4 and 8. Jefferson was a devoted aunt who loved to spend quality time with her nephews. She often took them to arcades and playgrounds. She was also a pet lover and a pillar of family life. She was 28 years old.

In the late evening of March 18, 2018, Stephon Clark, a 22-year-old African American man, was shot and killed in Sacramento, California, in the backyard of his grandmother's house. The officers involved in the fatal shooting of Clark were responding to a 911 call that a man wearing a black hoodie was breaking car windows. The encounter was filmed by police video cameras and by a Sacramento County Sheriff's Department helicopter which was involved in observing Clark. The officers stated that they shot Clark, firing 20 rounds, believing that he had pointed a gun at them. Police found only a cell phone on him. While the Sacramento County Coroner's autopsy report concluded that Clark was shot seven times, including three shots to the right side of the back, the pathologist hired by the Clark family stated that Clark was shot eight times, including six times in the back. The shooting caused large protests in Sacramento, and Clark's family members have rejected the initial police description of the events leading to his death. The Sacramento Police Department placed the officers on paid administrative leave and opened a use of force investigation. Police have stated that they are confident that Clark was the suspect responsible for breaking windows in the area prior to the encounter. On March 2, 2019, the Sacramento County district attorney announced that the police officers who killed Clark would not be charged and that they had probable cause to stop Clark and were legally justified in the use of deadly force.

Stephon Clark (born Stephan Alonzo-Clark,[3] August 10, 1995 – March 18, 2018) graduated from Sacramento High School in 2013, where he was on the football team. His 16-year-old brother was killed in a shooting in 2006.   Clark had been released from county jail about a month before the shooting and was staying with his grandparents on and off. At the time of his death he was on probation for a 2014 robbery conviction. Multiple leaders in the community opined that Clark's criminal record was immaterial to his death. He was 22 years old.

On July 6, 2016, office Jeronimo Yanez pulled Philando Castile over as a part of a traffic stop. Yanez had received radio info that the "occupants [of Castile's car] just look like people that were involved in a robbery." Dash cam footage shows Castile remained cooperative. Castile handed over his proof of insurance and informed the cop that he had a firearm in the car and was licensed to carry, at which point Yanez escalated the situation. Yanez shot Castile point blank seven times. Castile's fiancee, Diamond Reynolds, and her daughter were present in the car. A FB live video recorded by Reynolds shortly following the shooting gained nationwide attention. Officer Yanez was tried but not convicted. He was fired from the force, but he received $48,000 severance pay.

Philando Castile, a native of St. Louis, worked as a cafeteria supervisor at J.J. Hill Montessori Magnet School in Minnesota. His colleagues hail him as a role model to the hundreds of students he served. He had an immeasurably positive effect on the school’s community. Students remember him for his friendly demeanor and his attention to detail; he remembered each kid’s name and their dietary restrictions. He also frequently paid for students who could not afford their lunch. Castile's mother founded the Philando Castile Relief Foundation to help alleviate school lunch death and other victims of gun violence. He was 32 years old.

On February 26, 2012, in Sanford, Florida, George Zimmerman fatally shot Trayvon Martin, a 17-year-old African-American high school student. Zimmerman, a 28-year-old man, was the neighborhood watch coordinator for the gated community where Martin was visiting his relatives at the time of the shooting. Zimmerman called 911 to report a ‘suspicious person’ in the neighborhood.   Zimmerman shot Martin, who was unarmed, during a physical altercation between the two. Zimmerman, injured during the encounter, claimed self-defense in the confrontation. Martin’s father filed a missing persons report the next day, telling the authorities that his son had not returned from going to the store the previous evening. On March 12, 2012, Sanford Police Chief Bill Lee said that Zimmerman had not been charged because there are no grounds to disprove his version of the events. The next day, the Sanford Police Department’s homicide detective Christopher Serino recommends Zimmerman be charged with manslaughter. The case is then turned over to Florida State Attorney Norm Wolfinger. Robert Zimmerman, George Zimmerman’s father, wrote a letter to the Orlando Sentinel that stated his son has been unfairly portrayed as a racist, and that he is Hispanic and grew up in a multiracial family. The 911 calls from the night of the shooting were released on March 16, 2012. In a widely reported trial, Zimmerman was charged with murder for Martin's death, but acquitted at trial after claiming self-defense. The incident was reviewed by the Department of Justice for potential civil rights violations, but no additional charges were filed, citing insufficient evidence.

Trayvon Martin was born in 1995 in Miami, Florida. When Martin was nine years old, he saved his father's life by pulling his father, who had been immobilized by burns to the legs, out of a fire in their apartment. Martin enjoyed sports video games. Martin's former football coach said Martin had been one of the best players on their football team (The Wolverines) that played at Forzano Park. Martin played for the Wolverines from age 8 to 13, and sometimes sat out because his father benched him "because he messed up in school”. Martin had played football at the park since he was five years old and his team was coached in part, by his father. During his years in high school, Martin volunteered at Forzano Park, working in the concession stand, sometimes staying until 8 or 9 p.m., before going home. Martin had wanted to fly or repair airplanes and in mid-2009, enrolled in "Experience Aviation", a seven-week program run by award-winning aviator Barrington Irving. According to Irving, Martin was a polite youth "[who] reminded me of myself because I had a strong interest in football until I fell in love with aviation." After Martin graduated from the program, he spent the next summer as a volunteer, helping out new students in the aviation program. Martin was 17 years old.

On August 9, 2014 Officer Darren Wilson fatally shot Michael Brown in the city of Ferguson, Missouri. The police office was responding to a call about a baby with breathing problems. Brown allegedly stole a pack of cigars from a shop and pushing the store clerk into a display case when confronted. Shortly after this incident, police officer Darren Wilson received an alert in his patrol car. There is an altercation between Officer Wilson and Mr. Brown, who is standing at the window of the vehicle. Officer Wilson fires two shots from inside the vehicle, one likely grazing Mr. Brown’s thumb, and the other missing him. As Mr. Brown runs, officer Wilson pursues him on foot and fires four more shots, killing Michael Brown fatally.

At the time of his death, Brown had recently graduated from high school and was ancitipating his freshman year at Vatterott College. He had plans to become a heating and cooling technician. Brown loved video games, hanging out with friends, and listening to and writing music. He even posted songs he wrote on the popular music-sharing site Soundcloud under the handle "Big'Mike." Family and friends remember Brown as a 'gentle giant,' someone who preferred peace to confrontation. Shortly before his death, his family influenced him to embrace Christianity. Brown was 18 year old.

12-year-old Tamir Rice was playing with an airsoft gun in a Cleveland park when officers Timothy Loehmann and and Frank Garmback approached him. The officers were responding to a police dispatch call concerning a “Black male, maybe 20," with a "black revolver." Loehmann and Garmack claim they were unaware of Rice's age, and that Rice reached into his pockets as if to pull out a weapon. Loehmann shot Rice twice in the torso. Video footage shows the officers then forcing Tamir’s 14 year old sister to the ground, handcuffing her, and placing her in the back of the cop car. The 911 caller said that the gun was probably fake and that the holder of it was probably juvenile; but the dispatcher failed to relay this information and the responding officers failed to do their job. Neither officer was indicted.

Rice excelled at many sports, including football, basketball, ping pong, and swimming; he would even play against the older kids. “He can do it all. And I literally mean it all”, said Samaria Rice about her son. His parents claimed that he could have given Lebron James a run for his money one day. Rice was also passionate about video games, Batman, Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles, Legos, drawing cartoon characters, and pottery.

In Charlotte, NC, Jonathan Ferrell crashed his car and knocked on the door of a nearby home to seek help. The homeowner called the police and three officers responded to the scene, including Thornell Little and Randall “Wes” Kerrick. As the unarmed Ferrell ran towards them, Little fired his taser to no effect. Kerrick then opened fire, hitting Ferrell with ten of his twelve shots. Kerrick turned himself in and was charged with voluntary manslaughter, but court proceedings ultimately ended in a jury deadlock. In 2015, the city settled a lawsuit with the Ferrell family in which the latter was awarded $2.25 million.

Ferrell was a graduate of Florida A&M University and a member of its football team during their 2010 championship season. His brother, Willie, played alongside him. After Ferrell's death, Ferrell's coach noted that he was a leader on the team. Family and friends remember Ferrell for his commitment to helping others. "He had the softest heart of anybody," recalled his friend, Quenton Williams. Ferrell was engaged at the time of his death. He was 24 years old.

At around 1 a.m., McBride crashed her car in Detroit, MI. 911 callers notified the police of McBride's crash and seemingly 'discombobulated' state, but when EMS arrived, McBride was not by her car. She had walked to nearby Dearborn Heights in search of help. At around 4:40 a.m., McBride knocked on the door of Theodore Wafer's house. Wafer opened his door and fired a shotgun directly at McBride's head, killing her. Wafer claims he 'feared for his life' and 'accidentally' fired his gun; but on August 7, 2014, the court found him guilty of second-degree murder, manslaughter, and possession of a firearm during comission of a felony. He was sentenced to 17-32 years in prison.

McBride was a recent graduate of Southfield High School, where she had been a cheerleader. Friends and family remember McBride for her vibrant, outgoing personality. She loved to sing and joke around with her loved ones. One of McBride's cousins recalled that McBride wanted to be a police officer. McBride had family members who had passed away from violence, and she wanted to do what she could to spread love throughout her community. She was 19 years old.

Around 11 p.m., police officers responded to a call concerning "underage drunk kids" wandering around a party in Balch Springs, TX. Officers claim that upon arrival to the scene, they heard gunfire that caused the crowd to scatter. In response, officer Roy Oliver fired three rifle rounds through the front passenger window of an escaping vehicle, fatally striking 15 year old Edwards in the head. Edwards was brought to a hospital where he was declared dead, and police took Edwards' brother into custody for overnight questioning. Oliver was placed on administrative leave and later turned himself in after being charged with murder. On August 28, 2018, the court found Oliver guilty of Edwards' murder and sentenced him to 15 years.

Edwards was a freshman at Mesquite High School. He was a member of the football team and a model student, praised by his peers for his intelligence, work ethic, and smile. His mother recalled that Edwards was a classic 'social butterfly.' "Our family will never be the same; the kids will never be the same," remarked Edward's mother.

Around 7:30 p.m., Davis and four friends stopped by a gas station in Jacksonville, FL for some snacks. One of Davis's friends went into the store while the rest waited in the car. Couple Michael Dunn and Rhonda Rouer then pulled up next to Davis's car. While Rouer went into the store, Dunn expressed disgust at the "thug music" or "rap crap" coming from Davis's car. Dunn told Davis and friends to turn the music down, but Davis resisted. An argument then ensued. One witness recalls Dunn threatening, "You aren't going to talk to me like that." Dunn pulled out his handgun and fired at Davis, shooting him in the legs, lungs, and aorta. Even as Davis's car backed away, Dunn continued to fire. After Davis's car left, Dunn and Rouer left the scene; neither contacted the police. Davis died from his injuries. On February 14, 2014, Dunn was found guilty of three attempts of attempted murder. He was sentenced for life without parole.

Davis split his time between his mother's home in Marietta, GA and his father's in Jacksonville, FL. At the time of his death, Davis was living with his father and had made a name for himself in school. He was popular, made good grades, and had a girlfriend. Davis liked expensive sneakers, Armani cologne, and playing football and basketball. Friends and family remember him for his kind yet competitive spirit. In January 2015, a documentary recounting Davis's story, 3 1/2 Minutes, 10 Bullets, premiered at the Sundance Film Festival. Davis was 17 years old.

Aiyana Jones was in her house in Detroit, MI, sleeping next to her grandmother on the couch, when a SWAT team threw a flash grenade through her home window. The SWAT team invaded Jones' home in search of a shooting case suspect. Once in the house, officer Joseph Weekley shot Aiyana Jones in the head with his MP5 submachine gun, killing her. Weekley claimed Jones' grandmother attempted to knock Weekley's gun away from him, resulting in the shot. Weekley was tried twice for involuntary manslaughter, but after a retrial in 2015, the court dismissed Weekley's charges. As of 2017, Weekley is still an active duty Detroit police officer.
Aiyana loved princesses. In a popular photo that circulated after her death, she can be seen surrounded by Cinderella, Snow White, and Ariel. She was 7 years old.

Bell was with friends in Queens celebrating and anticipating his wedding, which was to occur the next day. As they left a club, an argument ensued. Gescard Isnora, a plainclothes officer, believed he heard one of Bell's friends mention a gun. In response, Isnora followed Bell's group, notified other officers, and confronted Bell, attempting to keep Bell from driving away. As Bell resisted and began to drive, Isnora called for the officers to open fire at Bell's car. Bell was struck four times and died from his injuries. His friends, Joseph Guzman and Trent Benefield, were severely wounded but survived.  Isnora claims that he and other officers identified themselves as they approached, but witness testimony conflicts this claim. Officers Isnora, Michael Oliver, and Marc Cooper were tried, but the court acquitted all three men in April 2008. In 2012, however, these men and their commanding officer were either forced to resign or fired.

Bell was a man of many talents. In high school, he pitched baseball and achieved an 11-0 record, but he was also artistic and liked taking acting lessons. At the time of his death, he was studying to be an electrician. Bell's uncle, college basketball coach Frank Haith, remembers Bell as "a good kid who was looking forward to getting married and beginning a new chapter in his life." Bell is survived by his fiancée, Nicole Paultre, and their daughter, Jada.

Grant had celebrated New Year’s Eve with friends in San Francisco and was on his way home on the Bay Area Rapid Transit (BART) with his girlfriend, Sophina. On the train, a fight occurred between Grant and an acquaintance that was successfully broken up, but not before police were called to the scene. At the Fruitvale station in Oakland, BART officers Tony Pirone and Marysol Domenici singled out Grant and other men as suspects in the skirmish. Pirone and officer Johannes Mehserle eventually positioned Grant face-down on the platform; as the former knelt on Grant’s neck, Mehserle pulled out his gun and fired a shot into Grant’s back. He died seven hours later. Mehserle was found guilty of involuntary manslaughter in July 2010. Pirone was fired for excessive use of force and misconduct.

Grant's mother, Wanda Johnson, remembers her son as "an encourager...he would try to say the very thing to make you laugh, to make you not dwell on the hurt or pain you would feel." In his youth, he was an active member of his church and enjoyed fishing, basketball, and baseball. Grant worked as a butcher in Oakland at the time of his death, but had dreams of becoming a barber. He and his girlfriend Sophina had a daughter, Tatiana, in 2005. He was 22 years old.

On July 10, Bland was pulled over by Texas state trooper Brian Encinia for a minor traffic violation. Both dashcam footage and Bland’s own 39-second phone video show the interaction quickly escalating, culminating with Encinia taking Bland into custody. Her bail was set at $5,000. A few days later, Bland was found hanging in her jail cell in an apparent suicide. Encinia was charged with perjury after falsifying statements about Bland’s arrest, but the charge was dropped when he agreed to resign from law enforcement. In 2016, Bland’s mother settled a $1.9 million wrongful death lawsuit against the county jail and police department.

One of five sisters, Bland was "a tough girl and a strong girl." She attended Prairie View A&M University, where she was a sister of Sigma Gamma Rho and graduated with a degree in agriculture. She served as a summer counselor, played in the marching band, and volunteered for a senior citizens advocacy group. After moving back home to Illinois to for six years, she was set to return to Prairie View to start a temporary job as a summer program associate. Bland was also an outspoken critic of police brutality and a member of the Black Lives Matter movement. In one of her many video commentaries posted to her Facebook, she said: "In the news that we've seen as of late, you could stand there, surrender to the cops, and still be killed." She was 28 years old.

Jones, a musician, was driving home to Boynton Beach, FL from a show, when his car broke down. He was on the phone with roadside assistance when a plainclothes police officer, Nouman Raja, approached his vehicle. According to Raja's claims, the 'abandoned vehicle,' warranted Raja burglary surveillance. Raja claims that while he was investigating, an armed Jones 'confronted' him. Raja then fired at Jones six times, shooting Jones in three places including Jones' aorta, which proved fatal. Raja wasn't wearing a body camera, but audio calls reveal that Raja never identified himself as an officer to Jones.  Jones' body was found a good distance away from the vehicle, suggesting he attempted to run. Jones had a gun, which had not discharged during the event, and he possessed a concealed to carry license. In April 2019, Raja was sentenced to 25 years in prison.

Jones graduated from the University of Akron, where he majored in music and business administration. At the time of his death, he worked as an inspector and property manager for the Delray Beach Housing Authority and also volunteered as a mentor for My Brother's Keeper, building relationships with Black youth. Jones was passionate about music and spent his free time playing drums at church and with his band Future Prezidents. Jones was very close to his large extended family, several of whom played in the NFL. "Anybody that knows Corey [knows] he would definitely be the face of inspiring change," remarked Jones' brother, C.J.  He was 31 years old.

On August 5th, John Crawford was shopping at a Walmart in Beavercreek, Ohio and picked up a toy BB gun that was for sale in the sporting goods section. Ronald Ritchie, spotting Crawford with the item, called 911 and reported that Crawford was holding a gun at customers. Police officers raced to the scene and cornered Crawford. Officer Sean Williams shot Crawford in the arms and chest without verbal warning and without giving time for Crawford to drop the toy gun. Crawford later died from his injuries. Security camera footage later revealed that at no point did Crawford point the toy gun at any person in the store. Neither officer was indicted, and officer Sean Williams remains on the Ohio police force.

Crawford was close to his family and loved spending time with his girlfriend, LeeCee Johnson, and their two sons, John IV and Jayden. Crawford's dad recalled that his son liked to watch the Weather Channel, and would have perhaps gone back to school to become a meteorologist. At the time of Crawford's death, he was 'getting his life back together' and focused on his future goals. He was 22 years old.

Terence Crutcher, later revealed to be under PCP influence, parked his car in the middle of a street in Tulsa, OK. Several called 911 to report the car, but even before officers responded to the call, officer Betty Shelby approached Crutcher to ask if the car belonged to him. Shelby claims Crutcher did not respond, at which point she drew her gun and ordered Crutcher to get onto his knees. Crutcher again did not comply, and by this time other officers had also arrived. Video footage shows Shelby and other officers follow Crutcher as he walks to his car with his arms raised. They claim they believed Crutcher reached into his car for a weapon, which is when officer Tyler Turnbough tasered Crutcher while Shelby shot Crutcher. Crutcher died from his injuries later that day. Officer Shelby was found not guilty and currently works as a sheriff's deputy.
At the time of his death, Crutcher was studying music at Tulsa Community College. He was an active member of the church and sang in the church choir. He was 40 years old.

At 5 a.m., Glover was walking with his stepfather, Add Armstead, to Armstead's workplace in Queens, NY. Two undercover police officers, Thomas Shea and Walter Scott, stopped the pair, claiming they resembled two men reported for taxi robbery. Since the officers were undercover, Armstead and Glover believed they were being robbed by the officers, and they attempted to flee the scene. Shea claims he spotted Glover with a weapon, at which point he fired at Glover, killing him. No weapon was found at the scene. Shea was tried but found not guilty; the jury was comprised of 11 white and one Black juror. Glover's murder sparked protests in the South Jamaican neighborhoods of Queens.

Glover's family fondly recalled family dinners and evenings they'd spend watching cowboy shows on televison. His parents, Add Armstead and Eloise Glover, have passed away; but Glover is survived by his siblings Darlene, Kenneth, Pauline, and Patricia. He was 10 years old.

On the night of September 15th 1973, 14-year-old Claude Reese and four other friends were renovating a tenement basement for a party. A neighbor called the cops for a noise complaint coming from the basement fearing burglary. When the officer showed up, the kids ran. Officer Frank Bosco shot Reese in the head, killing him. Bosco claimed he believed Reese was in possession of a gun, but it was revealed that this was not the case and that Reese only held a hand saw for the renovations. The jury cleared Bosco of charges of negligance and stated he acted reasonably in defense, and Bosco resumed officer duty by December 1974.
Reese was a native of Brooklyn. Following his death, 500 people from his community gathered outside of Reese's home to show solidarity and rally in protest of his unjust death. He was 14 years old.

On Thanksgiving night, Brooklyn police received reports of a man with a gun located at the Cypress Hill housing projects. Six officers responded and settled the matter. Officer Robert Torsney made one last walk around the building, at which point he confronted Evan and five friends. One of Evan's friends, Mark Williams, recalls that Evan asked officer Torsney if he had gone into 'apartment 70,.' Officer Torsney responded 'damned right,' shot Evans point blank in the head, killing him, and then ran back towards his cop car. Torsney was charged with murder, but he pled insanity and was found not guilty.
Randolph Evans was a ninth grader at Franklin K. Lane Highschool in Brooklyn. His neighbor described him as “a friendly child…he loved life.” He was 15 years old.

On December 3rd 1987, 28 year old Smallwood was arrested for alleged second-degree assault and for resisting arrest after protesting a friend’s driving summons. After her arrest, she was transported between Rikers prison, the courts, and hospitals, where she was treated for weakness and dizziness. Doctors noticed multiple bruises on her of unknown origins. Smallwood's family explained that the police beat Smallwood on multiple occassions, causing these injuries. On December 9th, sixth days after her arrest, Smallwood died due to a blood clot in her leg. Medical examiners said that the blood clots could have been formed because of the assault, but could not say for sure.
Smallwood was an immigrant from Kingston Jamaica. Living in the Bronx, she worked as a dietician aid and home health-care attendant. She is survived by her four children. She was 28 years old.

In the early hours of February 4th, 1999, four plain clothes cops (Edward McMellon, Sean Carroll, Kenneth Boss, and Richard Murphy) stopped and pursued Diallo on the grounds that he matched the description of a reported serial rapist. Diallo had been standing outside of the apartment building where he lived. As the officers pursued him, Diallo ran towards his apartment. Officers claim they saw Diallo reach into his pocket, at which point they fired 41 times, shooting Diallo 19 times. Investigation found no weapons on Diallo and eye witness accounts testify that the officers shot without warning.  All four cops responsible were charged with second degree murder but were acquitted.

Amadou Dilla was part of a notable Fulbe trading family in Guinea. He was born in Liberia, lived in Togo, Singapore, Thailand, and Guinea before immigrating to New York to start a business with his cousin. He worked as a street merchant selling socks, gloves, and video tape. He sent most of his income  back home to Guinea to support his family. He was 23 years old

In the parking lot of an autoparts shop in North Charleston, SC, police officer Michael Slager stopped Walter Scott, presumably for a broken tail light. Bystander footage shows Slager and Scott talked briefly before Scott turned and ran. Slager pursued Scott and the two came to blows. At one point, Slager tasered Scott. As Scott fled, Slager then proceeded to fire at Scott's back eight times. One shot penetrated Scott's lungs and heart, killing him. Slager pled guilty to second degree murder and was sentenced to 20 years in prison.

Walter Scott was a Coast Guard veteran and a dedicated father of four. At the time of his death, he was working as a forklift driver and was studying to become a massage therapist. A a born-again Christian, Scott worshipped regularly at WORD Ministries Christian Center. He was 50 years old.

NYPD officer Peter Liang and his partner were on vertical patrol, a regular patrol of housing projects in which cops looks for loitering or crime. They and Akai Gurley had both just entered a pitch-black stairwell when Liang's gun went off. Gurley was shot in the chest by Liang's ricochet bullet in the stairwell of the Brooklyn public housing. Barely breathing and unable to speak, he died within minutes. His girlfriend, Melissa Butler, attempted to perform CPR despite having no training, while the two officers on the scene with proper training did nothing. It took at least seven minutes for either officer to call in the shooting. The shot was deemed an accidental discharge, and Liang was sentenced to five years of probation and 800 hours of community service.

Akai Gurley was father to two and engaged. He liked to look good, and was known for having a well-organized closet and a good fashion sense. In his youth he was fondly referred to as "Grasshopper," constantly moving from one moneymaking scheme to the next. Friends recall he looked out for them, even going so far as to fill their pantry with food when they just asked for a little money to hold them over. He was 28 years old.

At around 1 a.m., Officer Roger Garcia responded to a 911 call about a domestic dispute in Hockaday’s Oxnard, California apartment. The call was made by Hockaday’s fiancé, Luis Galdo, who reported that she had been drinking and was becoming violent. Twenty seconds into Garcia’s arrival, Hockaday rushed towards Galdo with a knife in her hand. Galdo hid behind Garcia as Hockaday continued to advance, resulting in Garcia firing four shots at Hockaday. She died at the scene. Garcia was placed on administrative leave after the shooting, but has since returned to active duty.

Hockaday was a graduate of Santa Barbara High School. She was a mother to three girls, who were 7 months old, 2 years old, and 4 years old at the time of her death. She is survived by them, her mother, and her older sister. Hockaday was 26 years old.

On November 22, 2018, Emantic Fitzgerald Bradford Jr. was shot three times from behind and killed by police at the Riverchase Galleria Shopping Mall in Hoover, Alabama. Police were responding to a shooting at the mall. Another African-American man suspected in the shooting was arrested in Georgia a week later and charged. Bradford was holding a legally owned weapon when he was shot and had not been involved in the shooting incident. The shooting of Bradford was immediately controversial, and was condemned by the Alabama NAACP as an example of racially biased policing. A year later, Bradfords family sued the unnamed police officer for wrongful death. The lawsuit alleges that the office did not follow their training, violated department policy by not turning on their body-worn camera, failed to issue verbal commands before opening fire and did not verify whether Bradford posed a threat before killing him. The lawsuit claims that the office ‘admits that [they] never gave Bradford any verbal warning or command from which [they] could further assess and verify Bradfords status as either (a) an innocent civilian and/or first responder, or (b) a credible threat.’ This suit also emphasizes that Alabama is an open carry state and that Bradford had pistol and concealed carry permits. Alabama Attorney General Steve Marshall issued a report in February 2019 that called the shooting ‘justified’ and said he would not present the case to a grand jury.

Emantic "EJ" Fitzgerald Bradford Jr. was born on June 18, 1997.  He attended Holy Family Cristo Rey High School in Birmingham and earned his diploma through the GED program.   Bradford had enlisted in the Army in 2017 and completed basic training, but was administratively separated in August 2018 before completing advanced individual training. Bradford worked full time and was a caretaker for his father, a former correctional officer, with cancer.

At around 9:10 in the morning, three Baltimore police officers arrived at the Korryn Gaines' apartment to serve arrest warrants for her and her fiance, Kareem Courtney. Although police obtained a key to enter the apartment, an officer kicked in the door after knocking went unanswered. The officers saw Gaines sitting in her apartment with her five-year-old son and a shotgun. At 9:31 a.m., the police reported a barricade situation and called in a SWAT unit. After hours of negotiation, Officer Royce Ruby Jr. fired multiple shots at Gaines, killing her. Her young son was wounded in the gunfire, but survived. In 2018, a jury found Officer Ruby guilty of a civil rights violation and awarded damages to Gaines' family, but a year later, Judge Mickey J. Norman overturned the decision.

Gaines was a mother to a son and a daughter. She graduated from Baltimore City College in 2010 and attended Morgan State University for a semester. Gaines worked as a hairstylist and was an avid reader.

On April 12th, 2019, Booker was a victim of transphobic assault. She had multiple assailants at once, who inflicted physical harm, and emotional harm by shouting transphobic slurs. One perpetrator, Edward Thomas, was bribed with $200 to partake; he was later charged with aggravated assault. This incident was witnessed by many bystanders and was later made public online via a viral video of the event. A month later, Booker was murdered along with two friends. Kendrell Lavar Lyles was arrested and charged for this.

Muhlaysia Booker was a transgender woman born on January 14th 1997. After her attack, members of the black LGBT+ community in Dallas held a rally to demonstrate their support for her. She spoke at the event, thankfully stating "I will remain strong with your support."

Jamel Floyd was an inmate at Metropolitan Detention Center. On June 3, the Federal Bureau of Prisons claims that Floyd was being “disruptive” in his cell and was trying to break the cell door window with a metal object. Staff members pepper-sprayed Floyd and he died of a heart attack, even though correctional officers should have been aware that he had underlying medical conditions, including asthma. There is indication that Floyd was pepper sprayed excessively, since pepper spray is not supposed to be fatal, according to expert Jose Saldana, the director of Release Aging People in Prison. This is a horrific example of Metropolitan Detention Center’s ongoing poor conditions, since just last winter, people had to protest the fact that MDC had no heat or hot water for inmates. Jamel Floyd’s death is under investigation with US Marshals and the FBI notified. Some are calling for independent investigation, and many wish to see security footage, autopsy findings, and medical records. No officers have been charged.

Jamel Floyd was moved into the Metropolitan Detention Center on October 30, 2019 as part of his 15-year prison sentence after a jury convicted him of burglary and other crimes in Long Island, N.Y. in 2007. Previously, he was in Sing Sing prison, and it is not clear why he was moved to a federal detention center. Before his murder, he and his wife talked about the meal she was going to make for his first night out, and he and his 14-year-old daughter talked about their first father/daughter dance. He was 35 years old.

Officers Garrett Rolfe and Devin Brosnan were called to investigate a man sleeping in a car parked in a Wendy's parking lot in Atlanta on the evening of June 12th. Brooks engaged in a forty-one minute conversation with officers that was described as "cordial" by District Attorney Paul L. Howard Jr. After failing a sobriety test, Rolfe and Brosnan attempted to handcuff Brooks, resulting in a scuffle in which Brooks grabbed an officer's taser. According to Howard, the scuffle ensued because Rolfe grabbed Brooks' waist from behind without properly notifiying him what he was under arrest for beforehand. Brooks tried to flee the scene while holding the taser, and was then shot by Rolfe. Brooks died due to two gunshot wounds in his back. After the shooting, Rolfe uttered "I got him" and kicked Brooks, while Brosnan stood on Brooks' arm. Rolfe faces eleven charges, including felony murder, and Brosnan has been charged with aggravated assault. Protestors set the Wendy's where the incident occurred on fire and held a march to the Georgia state capital following Brooks' murder.

Brooks was a father of four, and described as a simple, family man. His niece Chassidy Evans stated that he "was silly, had the brightest smile and the biggest heart, and loved to dance since we were kids." Brooks had planned to take his eight year old daughter ice skating for her birthday the weekend that he was murdered. Brooks was vocal about his past of incarceration, and was working towards mending relationships with his family on account of this. Brooks has expressed outrage over the American prison system, citing how much public shame and job rejection he experienced as a result of being incarcerated. He had plans to move to Ohio in order to better support his family through work in construction there. He was 27 yeras old.

On May 20, 2019, in Oklahoma City, a 911 call came in that reported that there was a man who pulled a gun on another man in a parking lot near a taco truck. When the police arrived, Derrick Scott initially put his hands in the air, but then turned to run across the parking lot. Two officers chased him and one tackled him, straddling him. Scott began to say “I can’t breathe” to which the officer responded “I don’t care” and another stated “You can breathe just fine.” Scott continued to say “I can’t breathe” and repeatedly asked for his medicine, since he did have asthma. Later, an officer said “He’s acting like he’s unconscious.” They did not believe he was really passed out. He woke up momentarily but was loaded into an ambulance again and became unresponsive. An hour after his arrest, he was pronounced dead with the medical examiner declaring that the cause of death was a collapsed right lung. Derrick Scott’s mother did not learn of her son’s death for four days. The body camera footage was only recently released in June 2020 as a result of the Black Lives Matter protests. The three officers involved in the incident were cleared of misconduct.

Not much is known about Derrick Scott. He is survived by his mother, Vicki Scott Williams, a son, Derrick Ollie Scott Jr., a daughter Aaliyah, and two grandchildren, Malea and Zion. He was 42 years old.

Darrien Hunt was shot by police in Saratoga Springs, Utah outside of a Panda Express restaurant after dressing up/cosplaying as one of his favorite anime characters with a toy sword as part of the costume. The police officers were responding to a 911 call reporting a man with a samurai-style sword. According to the first statement by Tim Taylor, the chief deputy attorney of Utah County, the police shot Hunt while he brandished a sword and lunged at officers. But it has been revealed in a medical autopsy that he was actually shot six times from behind, which raises questions on how someone can lunge at a police officer and be shot in the back at the same time. An eyewitness has stated that Hunt was trying to run away, and this was when officers shot him. The police officers involved did not face any criminal charges, and they were not interviewed about this incident until much later than it took place. Hunt’s mother was offered $900,000 to drop her lawsuit against the city and the two police officers; she refused.

Darrien Hunt was something of a rarity in Saratoga Springs that, according to the 2010 census, is 93% white and 0.5% black. Hunt is survived by his mother, who is white and solely believes that racism played a major part in why her son was killed. He was simply portraying Mugen from Samurai Champloo. He was 22 years old.

After 11 PM on March 3, 2020, Manuel Ellis was walking home after playing drums that evening at church in Tacona, Washington. He had just called members of his family, explaining how happy he was. However, police claim that they had seen Ellis trying to open doors of occupied vehicles and appeared to be suffering from ‘excited delirium,’ which is family finds unlikely, based on his previous phone calls. They maintain that Ellis was not aggressive. At 11:21 PM on the corner of 96th Street South and Ainsworth Avenue South, police claim that Ellis started pounding on a Tacoma patrol car “for no apparent reason” and that when the officers got out, Ellis threw one of the officers to the ground. Then, one of the officers deployed a taser gun, striking Ellis in the chest, which is something that they left out in the initial police report. The police also placed themselves on top of Ellis. At 11:23 PM, two minutes after the encounter began, Ellis could be heard saying that he couldn’t breathe “sir,” in an attempt to be respectful to the officers. Then, the officers began to restrain Ellis with hobbles binding his legs, handcuffs on his wrists, and a “spit hood” over his mouth to prevent him from spitting or biting. Since Ellis was struggling to breathe, officers rolled him on his side and called for medical help.  Medics arrived at 11:34 PM and noted that he was deteriorating while they attempted CPR and placed a tube down his throat to help him breathe before he was pronounced dead at 12:12 AM. However, witness reports do not match up to the police statements. According to a witness, she thought that the police were having a friendly conversation before they, unprovoked, opened the car door and knocked Ellis down. They began punching him and the witness took a video of the encounter in which she is heard saying “Stop. Oh my God, stop hitting him. Just arrest him." The Pierce County medical examiner ruled that Ellis’ death was a homicide, resulting from hypoxia due to physical restraint. Other factors that could have contributed were high amounts of methamphetamine, body position, heart disease, and the “spit hood” used by the officers. The officers involved in Ellis’ death were initially put on administrative leave, but they returned to work after the police department ruled that there was no violation of policy. Meanwhile, Tacoma mayor Victoria Woodards is requesting at all officers involved be fired and prosecuted, so the officers have again been placed on leave. The state is conducting an independent investigation of the incident.

Manuel Ellis was a talented musician who played drums at the church up to four nights a week. He had an 11-year-old son and an 18-month-old daughter. He had struggled with addiction and mental health, but he was starting to turn his life around and living in a clean-and-sober house. Shortly before his murder, he was on the phone with his mother in which he told her “Remember I love you.” A vigil was held for Ellis in Tacoma on June 3. He was 33 years old.
